Address: 1 Epping Road, North Ryde, NSW, Australia
Why: When someone makes a purchase from Microsoft’s new store in Sydney, the vast majority of that cash ends up leaving the country. Microsoft sold about $2.1 billion in goods to Australian customers in its 2014 fiscal year, but only 5 percent of those sales were subject to Australia’s 30% corporate income tax. The rest was technically sold by an offshore company.
Notes: Microsoft sold about $2.1 billion worth of goods to Australian customers in its 2014 fiscal year, but only $100 million of that was recorded for tax purposes in Australia. The rest was by a Singapore sales unit.
calculation notes: Is assuming Singapore / Aus estimated revenue from Sample hearing wasn't passed up the chain, and profit accrued at the rough corporate rate. (Also estimated Irish tax based on the UK subsidiary ratio)
old why: Australia taxes business profits on companies with "permanent establishment" in the country. Because the vast majority of Microsoft sales are handled by a Singapore entity, they are not taxed in Australia.

Why: Microsoft uses Singapore-based Microsoft Regional Sales Corp. to sell to most Asian countries (Japan and Korea are notable exceptions). The company is technically a reseller, meaning that it is only subject to taxes on the commission it receives to sell the goods, which is substantially lower than the profit from the sale itself.
Notes: When Microsoft sold licenses to resell its software to this Singapore subsidiary in 2004, the deal projected the region's sales would be flat in the years ahead, an IRS audit found. Instead, the East Asian economies the Singapore unit sold to -- which were already booming at the time of the deal -- grew rapidly during the following decade.

Address: 1 Marina Boulevard, #22-01 One Marina Boulevard, Singapore
Why: Microsoft Regional Sales Corp. licenses the rights to sell Microsoft software from a Singaporean company known as Microsoft Operations. Because Microsoft Operations doesn’t actually own those rights, most of the proceeds from sales are sent to a corporate parent to cover licensing fees and are therefore not subject to taxation.
Notes: Microsoft Operations Singapore makes physical and digital copies of the company's software, and licenses them down the line to the company's sales force.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.
old why: Microsoft Operations licenses, but doesn't own, the rights to sell Microsoft software. That means it sends much of the money it makes, before taxes, to the Bermuda company it licenses the software from.

Address: Clarendon House, 2 Church Street, Hamilton, HM 11, Bermuda
Why: The rights to sell Microsoft products to customers in most Asian markets are owned by MAIL, located in Bermuda. Bermuda does not levy taxes on corporations. MAIL sends a portion of its sales proceeds to the U.S. to help cover Microsoft’s research costs. It has no employees, and its registered address is an offshoring law firm.
Notes: In exchange for an up-front payment to Microsoft – about $4 billion – and a commitment to pay a portion of Microsoft’s research costs, MAIL owns the economic rights to sell Microsoft’s software in its territory. The company has no employees.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.
old why: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.

Why: At the end of the line is Microsoft Singapore, one of Microsoft's three major sales hubs. Little else is known about this business.
Although Microsoft is headquartered in Redmond, Wash., only a small fraction of the proceeds from sales in Washington remain in-state.
The legal seller of most Microsoft products in the Western Hemisphere is actually located in Nevada, which has no corporate income tax.
Notes:
Since the late 1990s, Nevada has been the legal home to Microsoft’s sales of everything from Windows to Office and server tools. The state, known for minimal corporate taxes, regularly earns top marks in rankings measuring corporate-friendliness of state tax policy. 
Sales of Microsoft products to customers in the Western Hemisphere start in Reno. Then – for every product except Windows -- 47 percent of the cash from each sale goes to the island commonwealth of Puerto Rico without triggering U.S. federal income tax.
calculation notes: Charges full U.S. rate to 45% of the gross. Assumes 55% to PR, per Eli hoory testimony
old why: Nevada has no state corporate income tax. Through an arrangement in which Microsoft's Puerto Rico unit funds some company research, 46 percent of each U.S. sale goes directly to Puerto Rico without triggering U.S. federal income tax.

Why: More than half the cash from Microsoft's product sales, excluding Windows, ends up going offshore without triggering federal income tax. This cash is first transferred to a company in Puerto Rico, which owns the rights to sell Microsoft products throughout the Western Hemisphere and also helps fund company research. Microsoft pays Puerto Rican authorities a prearranged tax rate of only 1% to 2%. Tax analysts hired by Microsoft estimated this structure would reduce the company's U.S. taxable income by $38 billion over a 10-year period.
Notes:
In 2005, the Puerto Rican company bought the rights the rights to the software Microsoft sells throughout the Western Hemisphere.  
Tax analysts hired by Microsoft estimated the deal would reduce Microsoft’s U.S. taxable income by $38 billion over a 10-year period, an IRS investigator told a federal judge this year. 
The company negotiated an agreement with local regulators to pay a tax rate of 1%-2% before passing profit to a Bermuda parent.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.
old why: Microsoft negotiated an agreement with Puerto Rican regulators to pay a 2% income tax.

Why: Microsoft Puerto Rico is owned by a company known as MACS Holdings. This company is located in Bermuda, which has no corporate income tax.
Notes:
MACS Holdings was created to serve as the owner of Microsoft Puerto Rico, before ownership was transferred in a tax-free sale to an Irish company. Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations. 
A Senate committee found that the structure “is not designed to satisfy any specific manufacturing or business need; rather, it is designed to minimize taxes on sales of products sold in the United States.”
old why: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.

Address: Matheson, 70 Sir John Rogerson's Quay, Dublin 2, Ireland
Why: MACS Holdings is owned by an Irish company known as Round Island One. Though located in Ireland, Round Island One is also headquartered for tax purposes in Bermuda.
Notes: Though located in Ireland, Round Island One is headquartered, for tax purposes in Bermuda, meaning much of its income is taxable in the tax haven.
old why: Round Island One is the Irish hub that funnels Microsoft's retails sales from Europe and the Americas to Bermuda. The company is also the corporate parent of Microsoft's Irish finance units, which invest a portion of Microsoft's offshore cash.

Address: Clarendon House, 2 Church Street, Hamilton, HM 11, Bermuda
Why: At the end of the line is a company known as RI Holdings, also located in Bermuda. Its address is listed as a law firm that helps companies manage offshore business dealings.
Notes: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.
old why: Bermuda doesn't levy taxes on corporations.

Address: Thames Valley Park, Reading, Berkshire, UK
Why: The vast majority of Microsoft's proceeds from sales in the United Kingdom leave the country without triggering corporate income tax. Microsoft sold about $3.3 billion in goods to U.K. customers in its 2014 fiscal year, but the company’s local subsidiary only paid $28 million in income tax.
Notes: Microsoft's U.K. and Irish units had sales of $3.8 billion in the U.K. during the company's 2014 fiscal year. Because most of that revenue was passed on to Bermuda, Ireland and Luxembourg, Microsoft's U.K. marketing subsidiary paid about $16 million in taxes.
calculation notes: Gets to 7% if you EXCLUDE sales MIOL books outside of the country.
old why: Most sales to U.K. customers are treated as Irish income -- and untaxed in the U.K. -- because Microsoft's Irish sales subsidiary has no "permanent establishment" in the country.

Address: Atrium Building Block D, Carmenhall Road, Sandyford Industrial Estate, Dublin 18, Ireland
Why: Microsoft Ireland Operations Ltd. licenses the right to sell software to customers in Europe, the Middle East and Africa. Because it doesn’t own those rights, about 80% of sales are sent to a corporate parent to cover licensing fees and cover its own costs. Those payments aren’t subject to income taxes at this step.
Notes: Microsoft Ireland Operations employs 735 people, and during the 2014 fiscal year earned $1.2 million in profit per employee. The companywide average was $172,000 per employee.
calculation notes: 2.8% is assuming all of the turnover on MIOL's 2014 return was sourced to Ireland and taxed there, instead of up the chain in revenue payments. Senate report pegged effective rate at 7.3%.
old why: Ireland generally taxes companies on the income attributable to their Irish branch. Most of the sales the Irish unit collects are from the rest of Europe, and are passed on in the form of tax-deductible royalty payments to the corporate parent.

Why: Microsoft Ireland Operations Ltd. is owned by Microsoft Ireland Research, which exists primarily to license Microsoft products to its subsidiary and to pay a portion of the company’s total research costs.
calculation notes: Source is Senate report, effective rate in 2011.
old why: Despite its name, Microsoft Ireland Research primarily exists to buy the rights to Microsoft software from the U.S. company, and license the sales rights to an Irish subsidiary.

Address: Matheson, 70 Sir John Rogerson's Quay, Dublin 2, Ireland
Why: In turn, Microsoft Ireland Research is owned by a company known as Round Island One. Although Round Island One is located in Ireland, it is technically headquartered in the corporate tax haven of Bermuda.
Notes: Round Island One is the Irish hub that funnels Microsoft's retails sales from Europe and the Americas to Bermuda. The company is also the corporate parent of Microsoft's Irish finance units, which invest a portion of Microsoft's offshore cash.
old why: Though located in Ireland, Round Island One is headquartered, for tax purposes in Bermuda, allowing its profit to pass tax free to its parent company.
